intro: Bowdichia virgilioides, commonly known as the Florida hickory, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the legume family (Fabaceae) and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy, yellowish-white flowers. The tree produces small, edible nuts enclosed in a hard shell, which are a food source for various wildlife species. Its bark is thick and deeply furrowed, providing a distinctive appearance. Bowdichia virgilioides is often found in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to coastal and inland hardwood forests.
